A peaked function for modeling temperature dependence of plant productivity Georgii A. Alexandrov ⁎ g.alexandrov@nies.go.jp Yoshiki Yamagata National Institute for Environmental Studies, CGER/NIES, Onogawa 16-2, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305-8506, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +81 298 50 2974; fax: +81 298 50 2960. Abstract We suggests that temperature response of plant productivity can be modeled by the Arrhenius function modified to describe the effect of temperature on enzyme activity: G A(T)=2f(T)/(1+ f 2(T)), where f(T)=exp(E a/RT opt − E a/RT), R the universal gas constant, E a the activation energy and T opt is the optimal temperature. In common with other functions used for modeling the temperature response of plant productivity, the curve of function G is almost symmetrical and bell-shaped. The special convenience of G A is that it relates the width of the “bell” to thermodynamic concepts, such as activation energy of chemical reactions converting carbon dioxide and water to carbohydrates. Keywords Plant response to environment Photosynthesis Temperature response Arrhenius function Calibration 1 Introduction Temperature response of plant productivity is normally modeled by a peaked function (Adams et al., 2004; Vitale et al., 2003; Alexandrov et al., 2002; Ito and Oikawa, 2002; Birky, 2001; Huntingford et al., 2000; Svirezhev and von Bloh, 1997; Krapivin, 1993; Janecek et al., 1989) that often has no biophysical meaning by itself. It can be a polynomial, a Gaussian, or other ad hoc function expressing in mathematical form the basic idea that plant productivity starts decrease when temperature exceeds some critical value. Here we suggest certain theoretical ground for this basic idea: the theory of enzyme-mediated reactions. Since the synthesis of organic matter is a complex sequence of enzyme-mediated reactions, we suppose that this theory can serve as a guide for modeling temperature response of plant productivity. We proceed from the Arrhenius function modified to describe the effect of temperature on enzyme activity. This function, proposed by Johnson et al. (1942), has two drawbacks: it is awkward-to-handle, and it contains parameters that are difficult to calibrate either from theoretical speculations or from experimental data (Medlyn et al., 2002). We express this function in more convenient form and propose a transparent technique for calibrating its parameters. 2 Model 2.1 Normalized Arrhenius function Temperature dependence of a chemical reaction is often parameterized by the Arrhenius function: k = k 0 exp − E a R T where k is the rate coefficient, E a the activation energy, R the universal gas constant and T is the absolute temperature. If k =1 when T = T 0 then k 0 = exp E a R T 0 and hence k = exp E a R T 0 exp − E a R T = exp E a R T 0 − E a R T = exp E a ( T − T 0 ) T R T 0 Converting Kelvin to Celsius we obtain the alternative expression of the Arrhenius function, so called, the normalized Arrhenius function: (1) f A ( T ) = exp E a ( T − T 0 ) ( T + 273 ) R ( T 0 + 273 ) where T 0 is the temperature at which the function is equal to 1 (i.e., f A(T 0)=1). 2.2 Generalized Arrhenius function Enzyme-mediated reactions response to temperature in more complicated manner: high temperatures reduce the catalytic effect exerted by enzymes (Fig. 1 ). Therefore, the Arrhenius function is applicable only at relatively low temperatures. Johnson et al. (1942) modified the Arrhenius function to describe the effect of temperature on enzyme activity: (2) k = k opt H d exp [ H a ( T − T opt ) / T R T opt ] H d − H a ( 1 − exp [ H d ( T − T opt ) / T R T opt ] ) where T is absolute temperature, H a and H d are interpreted as the levels of activation energy below and above enzyme's temperature (T opt), respectively, and (3) T opt = H d Δ S − R log [ H a / ( H d − H a ) ] where ΔS is known as an entropy factor “but is not readily interpreted” (Medlyn et al., 2002). Let us denote η = H d H a Then we may rewrite the Eq. (2) as k = k opt η H a f A η H a − H a ( 1 − f A η ) = k opt η f A η − ( 1 − f A η ) = k opt η f A ( η − 1 ) + f A η and define the generalized Arrhenius function (4) G A ( T ) = η f A ( T ) ( η − 1 ) + f A η ( T ) which is equal to 1 when f A =1 (i.e., at T 0 = T opt). At low temperatures, this function is no different from an Arrhenius function. For example, the curve of f A (E a =65kJmol−1 and T 0 =45°C) shown in Fig. 2 by dashed line is well approximated by the curve of G A (shown by solid line) with the same activation energy, T opt =45°C, and η =36, when the temperature is lower than 45°C. However, the curves diverge sharply at higher temperature: f A(T) smoothly increases, whereas G A(T) drops to display denaturing of enzymes at the temperature above 45°C. The optimal temperature of an enzyme-mediated reaction is not always close to the temperature of enzyme denaturing. The temperature response of photosynthesis is often drawn as a bell-shaped curve centered somewhere between 20 and 30°C. This type of temperature response can be modeled with G A, if η =2 (Fig. 2, dotted line). 2.3 Calibration techniques Let us imagine that we measured the rate of light-saturated photosynthesis (p), which is indeed described by the function p ( T ) = p opt G A ( T ) n times at m levels of temperature (T j , j =1, 2, …, m), but the measurements are disturbed by a noise (ɛ jk , k =1, 2, …, n). Then, we have a series of n × m numbers p j , k = p opt G A ( T j ) + ε j , k containing information about the values of E a and T opt. In order to restore E a and T opt from the measurements we may use the mean values p ˆ j = p opt G A ( T j ) + ε ˆ j and thus reduce the noise. If p opt is known and η =2, then we need only two points { T 1 , p ˆ 1 } and { T 2 , p ˆ 2 } to estimate E a and T opt (5) E ˆ a = log ( y 1 / y 2 ) ( 1 / R T 2 ) − ( 1 / R T 1 ) ; T ˆ opt = T 1 1 + ( R T 1 / E ˆ a ) log ( y 1 ) ; where y i = p opt p ˆ i 1 − 1 − p ˆ i p opt 2 , i = 1 , 2. If p opt is not known, then we need a third point { T 3 , p ˆ 3 } for testing a guess about the true value of p opt and coming to the estimate ( p ˆ opt ) that minimize p ˆ 3 − p ˆ opt G A ( T 3 ) . In that case, y i = p ˆ opt p ˆ i 1 − 1 − p ˆ i p ˆ opt 2 , i = 1 , 2 2.4 Case study The proposed technique may be illustrated with the measured rates of light-saturated photosynthesis for the hot desert grass Tidestromia oblongifolia (Berry and Björkman, 1980) grown in hot environment (Fig. 3 ). If one will take the points {31.9, 39.5} and {40.7, 53.7} for estimating E a and T opt under given p opt, and point {49.5, 45.5} for testing a guess about the true value of p opt, then the coefficients of the function will be as follows p ˆ opt = 54 ( μ mol C O 2 ) m − 2 s − 1 ; E ˆ a = 66.2 kJ mo l − 1 ; T ˆ opt = 41.9 ° C and the curve of the function will go through these three points. Similarly, in case of the grass grown in cold environment, choosing the points {23.5, 8.4}, {28.0, 9.8} and {37.0, 7.5}, one will obtain p ˆ opt = 9.9 ( μ mol C O 2 ) m − 2 s − 1 ; E ˆ a = 77.6 kJ mo l − 1 ; T ˆ opt = 29 ° C 3 Concluding remarks In most cases the measurements are not precise, and hence the results of calibration depends on the choice of { T i , p ˆ i } , ( i = 1 , 3 ¯ ) . The proposed technique makes the relation between the accuracy of measurements and the accuracy of estimates to be transparent, shows how large is the variety of curves that may equally well fit the data. Even if the measurements are precise, the points lying at low and high temperatures may reflect not only response of the photosynthetic system but also the loss of system integrity. Therefore, it would be better to use the points lying somewhere between the optimum and extremes and to restrict the domain of the model to a relevant temperature range. In this connection it should be noted that the calibration technique proposed here is to provide some empirical justification for the use of G A function in carbon cycle models, not to prove that temperature response of photosynthesis must follow the pattern suggested by the proposed function. The latter goes beyond the scope of this study and needs specially designed experiments. The proposed function offers certain advantage over polynomial, Gaussian, or other ad hoc functions applied to modeling temperature response of plant productivity. It expresses the informal postulates and empirical generalizations in terms of chemical thermodynamics and links them to the thermodynamic theory of ecological systems (Jørgensen and Svirezhev, 2004). Thus, the informal postulate that the curve of temperature response should be almost symmetrical is expressed in the form of mathematical relationship between temperature, entropy and energy (Eq. (3), η =2): T opt Δ S E a ≈ 2 , that turns the postulate into the object of theoretical studies challenging the Jørgensen–Svirezhev theory (JST). This link to JST may play important role in reducing current uncertainties in quantifying climate feedbacks from terrestrial ecosystems. What is the temperature threshold at which ecosystems switch from net carbon sink to net carbon source? Models differ on this matter (Alexandrov and Yamagata, 2004). Moreover, the bulk of CO2 flux measurements cannot resolve per se the problem of quantifying climate impact on the productivity of terrestrial ecosystems (Alexandrov et al., 2005). One needs a theory that may serve as a basis for combining models and observations. JST seems to be the most appropriate candidate for this role in the context of computational and conceptual framework presented here. coredata.dc:description: Abstract We suggests that temperature response of plant productivity can be modeled by the Arrhenius function modified to describe the effect of temperature on enzyme activity: G A(T)=2f(T)/(1+ f 2(T)), where f(T)=exp(E a/RT opt − E a/RT), R the universal gas constant, E a the activation energy and T opt is the optimal temperature. In common with other functions used for modeling the temperature response of plant productivity, the curve of function G is almost symmetrical and bell-shaped. The special convenience of G A is that it relates the width of the “bell” to thermodynamic concepts, such as activation energy of chemical reactions converting carbon dioxide and water to carbohydrates.
coredata.dc:title: A peaked function for modeling temperature dependence of plant productivity
